Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Tracking Cognitive Functions with Ear-worn Bio-sensing Device
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this I-Corps project will be to enable bio-sensing earphones for personalized healthcare. It can benefit a wide range of systems and applications that require continuous and long-term personal monitoring, such as user behavior analysis, seizure suppression, sleep improvement, and personalized education. Currently, there are 3 billion people without access to healthcare who could potentially benefit from the device. Mobile healthcare is rapidly growing, emerging industry in need of a socially acceptable, platform technology to enable healthcare applications outside the hospital. This project will directly support national level initiatives on improving healthcare practices and enhancing future workforce capability. To make the broadest impact possible, the project will initially focus on individual customers, to improve lives in ways that were technologically impossible before. The potential innovation enables a mobile healthcare platform for everyday use with high accuracy, low cost, and high comfort to users.

This I-Corps project includes several innovations to enable previously impossible mobile physiological sensing. This ear-worn device enables everyday users to access the medically valuable physiological data from the human head in a comfortable, small, and wearable form factor placed in or around the ears. The project's algorithms, hardware, and software can infer the wearer's mental, physiological, and physical states from the ears. The resulting innovation enables immediate access to vital health information such as sleep deprivation, attention, and even seizure onset without using obtrusive, expensive hospital equipment. The team will evaluate the platform through customer discovery and other commercialization focused evaluations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to lay a commercial understanding for mobile healthcare via ear-worn sensing and actuation, called Earable. This project pursued (1) the assessment of commercial viability for a modular computing platform to simultaneously sense head-based physiological signals from inside and around the ears, (2) the exploration of insights into needs and expectations of the potential customers and stakeholders and the target market, and (3) the development of a thorough business strategy, that all will accelerate Earable's commercialization and enable this innovation in the emerging area of wearable health systems and pave the way for Earable systems at an unprecedented scale.

We first built a comprehensive analysis to ensure the commercial viability of the technology. We conducted multiple works on the target market research, the industry analysis, and the competitor analysis. We performed market research to uncover the potential consumers or companies that might buy our product as well as their size and characteristics. We also serve a clear vision of the strengths, weaknesses, and offerings of products in the same market. Leveraging such basic information, we understood the market gaps where we can exploit to demonstrate a valuable contribution and show opportunities and possible threats to defend our innovations to outperform competitors on the path of realizing our Earable technology.

As knowing the potential customers and stakeholders, parallelly, we planned to collect their conditions, opinions, needs, and expectations through actual interviews and interactions. We looked for corresponding groups, organizations, and companies that publicly operate and allow us to hold in-person meetings. We also developed questionnaires focusing on their interest in new technologies that can assist their condition, their comments on our product prototype, their expectation of benefits brought by our technology to their health condition or simply basic needs in daily life, etc. While preparing this plan, it was challenging for us to address the constraints of (1) data diversity, (2) customers? knowledge of hi-tech products, and (3) short-time operation for data collection so that we can quickly have applicable, unbiased information about the market. Hence, we searched public places running the operation of different groups relatively to application domains we are targeting. Within these groups, we tried to build a balanced number of customers with divergent criteria such as genders, proficiency in hi-tech products, aging range, etc. To overcome the constrained short-time operation, we worked on timing and logistics to possibly do many interviews at a sufficient number of places to further broaden the data collection. As a result, we were able to complete more than 125 interviews with our potential customers and stakeholders and generate an intensive, unbiased, reliable report for the potential of commercializing our Earable technology.

Finally, based on the market viability assessment, customer interviews, and stakeholder interactions for our novel and unexplored technology, we were able to build a thorough business plan to take the technology to the market. We took great benefits of the orientation for the technology development to decide the right path for our go-to-market strategy. As a result, we can clearly describe our vision of how to enter the market, what to offer the customers, how to make profits, and how to protect against potential pitfalls. Moreover, we achieve a coherent path to accomplish multiple goals, including MVP prototype, interview scheduling, FDA plan, and trademark filing, to name a few.

Overall, the project has enabled the team to collaborate and to gain experience with the challenges of building a startup on the ear-worn bio-sensing technology. The achievement in this project has been applied to our key product in the future launch. The results have also been disseminated in several other application domains through publications in academic conference proceedings and journals across the fields of computer and mobile sensing engineering.

In conclusion, the resulting knowledge and business strategy ultimately help to deliver an impact on adapting our novel technology to the strong desire expressed by individuals we had interviewed and the macropeconomic problems that remain unsolved. The I-Corps program is instrumental in accelerating our customer discovery process. We believe there is an immense commercial opportunity to realize Earable technology for personalized healthcare.


Last Modified: 08/21/2021
Modified by: Tam Vu
